key_points: Tiger Woods will not face charges following his car crash in California, as drugs and alcohol were ruled out.
Los Angeles County Sheriff Alex Villanueva confirmed Woods was not impaired during the accident.
There was no evidence of impairment, and Woods was described as 'lucid' with no need for sobriety tests.
The crash, involving a $50,000 Genesis GV80 SUV, occurred on a known dangerous stretch of road.
Woods was on his way to film a TV teaching lesson when the accident happened.
He suffered significant injuries and was extricated from the vehicle by Los Angeles County firefighters.
Woods underwent a long surgical procedure for his injuries at Harbor-UCLA Medical Center.
Dr Anish Mahajan detailed the extent of Woods' injuries and the emergency surgery performed.
This incident marks the third police investigation involving Woods and his driving.
Woods' participation in future golf events, including The Masters, is uncertain due to his injuries.
spokespersons: Anish Mahajan (Chief Medical Officer, Harbor-UCLA Medical Center)
